paragraphs.text:
%md

## Spark Streaming and Kafka Integration Demo

**In this example, we'll use spark streaming - actually rather the Spark SQL / Structured Streaming technology - to read some _financial transactions data_ from the Berka Dataset from a kafka input topic, enrich them a little and write them to a kafka output topic**

*A first python program (A) - paragraph 3 - will send transactions read from .eskimo to the input kafka topic. In addition, It will also read the result from the kafka output topic and dump these results on the console*
*Then a  second program (B) - paragraph 5 - implemented using Spark Structured Streaming will enrich these transactions read from the input kafka topic and send the result back to the output kafka topic*
*The first program (A) finally takes care of dumping these results to the console*


```
            ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓       ┏━━━━┓     ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓       ┏━━━━┓     ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
            ┃                     ┃       ┃ I  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ O  ┃     ┃                     ┃
┏━━━━┓      ┃      Program A      ┃       ┃ N  ┃     ┃     Program B       ┃       ┃ U  ┃     ┃      Program A      ┃
┃ ES ┃─────▶┃    Populate kafka   ┃──────▶┃ P  ┃────▶┃   Spark Streaming   ┃──────▶┃ T  ┃────▶┃   Dump on console   ┃
┗━━━━┛      ┃     Input topic     ┃       ┃ U  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ P  ┃     ┃                     ┃
            ┃                     ┃       ┃ T  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ .  ┃     ┃                     ┃
            ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛       ┗━━━━┛     ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛       ┗━━━━┛     ┗━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┛
Index:              Python                Topic:             Spark                  Topic:
berka-payments       Job             berka-payments          Job           berka-payments-aggregate
```


**Important Notes - READ CAREFULLY** :

* **Two sample notebooks must have been executed in prior to executing this one : the "Logstash Demo" and "Spark Integration ES", in this order**

msg.data:
Spark Streaming and Kafka Integration Demo

In this example, we’ll use spark streaming - actually rather the Spark SQL / Structured Streaming technology - to read some financial transactions data from the Berka Dataset from a kafka input topic, enrich them a little and write them to a kafka output topic

A first python program (A) - paragraph 3 - will send transactions read from .eskimo to the input kafka topic. In addition, It will also read the result from the kafka output topic and dump these results on the console
Then a second program (B) - paragraph 5 - implemented using Spark Structured Streaming will enrich these transactions read from the input kafka topic and send the result back to the output kafka topic
The first program (A) finally takes care of dumping these results to the console

            ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓       ┏━━━━┓     ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓       ┏━━━━┓     ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓

┗━━━━┛      ┃     Input topic     ┃       ┃ U  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ P  ┃     ┃                     ┃
            ┃                     ┃       ┃ T  ┃     ┃                     ┃       ┃ .  ┃     ┃                     ┃

Index:              Python                Topic:             Spark                  Topic:
berka-payments       Job             berka-payments          Job           berka-payments-aggregate

Important Notes - READ CAREFULLY :

  • Two sample notebooks must have been executed in prior to executing this one : the “Logstash Demo” and “Spark Integration ES”, in this order

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Prerequisite) Run following paragraph to create potentially missing kafka topics

msg.data: Prerequisite) Run following paragraph to create potentially missing kafka topics

paragraphs.text:
%sh

. /etc/eskimo_topology.sh

if [[ `kafka-topics.sh --zookeeper $MASTER_ZOOKEEPER_1:2181 --describe | grep -E "Topic: berka-payments[^-]+"` == "" ]]; then

    kafka-topics.sh \
        --create \
        --replication-factor 1 \
        --partitions 4 \
        --zookeeper $MASTER_ZOOKEEPER_1:2181 \
        --topic berka-payments
fi

if [[ `kafka-topics.sh --zookeeper $MASTER_ZOOKEEPER_1:2181 --describe | grep -E "Topic: berka-payments-aggregate[^-]+"` == "" ]]; then

    kafka-topics.sh \
        --create \
        --replication-factor 1 \
        --partitions 4 \
        --zookeeper $MASTER_ZOOKEEPER_1:2181 \
        --topic berka-payments-aggregate
fi

%md

### A) First program : reading Data from berka-payments index and periodically sending it to kafka input topic while also dumping on the console whatever comes on the kafka output topic

This first python program reads the input transaction data from ElasticCearch and sends them to the kafka topic used as input by the spark streaming program. It also takes care of reading the results from the kafka output topic and dump them results on the console.

**Important Notes**:

* **The dataset used from .eskimo is the dataset computed by the “Spark Integration ES” Demo notebook**

msg.data:
A) First program : reading Data from berka-payments index and periodically sending it to kafka input topic while also dumping on the console whatever comes on the kafka output topic

This first python program reads the input transaction data from ElasticCearch and sends them to the kafka topic used as input by the spark streaming program. It also takes care of reading the results from the kafka output topic and dump them results on the console.

Important Notes:

  • The dataset used from .eskimo is the dataset computed by the “Spark Integration ES” Demo notebook

paragraphs.text:
%python

from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch
import time, requests, json, sys, threading
from threading import Thread, Lock
from kafka import KafkaProducer, KafkaConsumer
from kafka.errors import KafkaError
import os, signal, sys

KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS=["kafka.eskimo.svc.cluster.eskimo:9092"]
ELASTICSEARCH_SERVER="elasticsearch.eskimo.svc.cluster.eskimo"

run = True

def handler(signum, frame):
    print("Received Signal: %d"%signum)
    run = False
    sys.exit (0);
    
signal.signal(signal.SIGTERM, handler)
signal.signal(signal.SIGHUP, handler)
signal.signal(signal.SIGINT, handler)

def connect_kafka_producer():
    _producer = None
    try:
        _producer = KafkaProducer(bootstrap_servers=KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS, api_version=(0, 10, 1))
    except Exception as ex:
        print('Exception while connecting Kafka')
        print(ex)
        sys.exit (-1);
    finally:
        return _producer

def connect_kafka_consumer():
    _consumer = None
    try:
        _consumer = KafkaConsumer(bootstrap_servers=KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS,
                         auto_offset_reset='latest',
                         consumer_timeout_ms=3600000)
    except Exception as ex:
        print('Exception while connecting Kafka')
        print(ex)
        sys.exit (-1);
    finally:
        return _consumer


# Cache reader class thread
class ReaderClass(threading.Thread):
    def __init__(self):
        threading.Thread.__init__(self)
        self.event = threading.Event()
        self.consumer = connect_kafka_consumer()
        self.consumer.subscribe(['berka-payments-aggregate'])

    def run(self):
        for message in self.consumer:
            if self.event.is_set():
                if self.consumer is not None:
                    self.consumer.close()
                break
            event = json.loads (message.value)
            print (json.dumps (event))

    def stop(self):
        self.event.set()

def publish_message(producer_instance, topic_name, key, value):
    try:
        key_bytes = key.encode ('utf-8')
        value_bytes = value.encode ('utf-8')
        #print('sending')
        producer_instance.send(topic_name, key=key_bytes, value=value_bytes)
        #print('flushing')
        producer_instance.flush()
        #print('Message published successfully.')
    except Exception as ex:
        print('Exception in publishing message')
        print (ex)
        sys.exit (-1);


es = Elasticsearch([{'scheme': 'http', 'host': ELASTICSEARCH_SERVER, 'port': 9200}])

kafka_producer = connect_kafka_producer()

# Launch reader thread
reader = ReaderClass()
reader.start()


res = es.search(index="berka-payments", body={"query": {"match_all": {}}}, scroll='15m', search_type='query_then_fetch', size=10000)

print("%d documents found - %d fetchable" % (res['hits']['total']['value'], len(res['hits']['hits'])) )

sid = res['_scroll_id']
scroll_size = res['hits']['total']['value']

counter = 0
print ("Sending payments to kafka ...")

# Start scrolling
while (scroll_size > 0 and run):

    page = es.scroll(scroll_id=sid, scroll='2m')

    # Update the scroll ID
    sid = page['_scroll_id']

    # Get the number of results that we returned in the last scroll
    scroll_size = len(page['hits']['hits'])

    for cur in page["hits"]["hits"]:
        
        if not run:
            sys.exit(0)
        
        data = cur["_source"]

        publish_message(kafka_producer, 'berka-payments', data['trans_id'], json.dumps(data))

        #print("(%s) - %s" % (data['trans_id'], json.dumps(data)))

        if counter % 10 == 0: 
            print ("Sent %d payments. waiting 2 seconds" % counter)
            time.sleep(2) 

        counter = counter + 1 

if kafka_producer is not None:
    kafka_producer.close()
    
time.sleep(8)     

if reader is not None:
    reader.stop()

%md

### B) Spark Streaming Program : reading from kafka input topic, computing aggregate and sending result to kafka output topic

This Spark SQL Structured Streaming programs reads some transactions from the Berka Dataset (resulting from the “Spark Integration ES” Demo notebook) from a kafka input topic as sent by the program A above. It then enriches them slightly and sends them back to a kafka output topic. The first program above then dumps them on the console.

**Important Notes**:

* *The Kafka bootstrap server is extracted from the Eskimo topology (variable SELF_IP_ADDRESS gives external IP Address and then SELF_MASTER_KAFKA_XXX gives kafka server to use)*
* **The logs of the spark driver are available in the spark zeppelkin interpreter logs which you shall find in `/var/log/zeppelin/zeppelin-interpreter-spark-*.log` on the node executing zeppelin**
* **CAUTION - SPARK STREAMING PROGRAM IS NOT PROPERLY TERMINATED BY ZEPPELIN !!! For this reason, a small paragraph is provided right hereafter so setup a specific name for the spark application which will be used in the last paragraph to stop (kill) the spark streaming program**

*Other notes*:

* In case you encounter an error such as *"java.lang.IllegalStateException: Cannot start query with id 9c7acfc7-da52-4282-a012-3c3cbd8aa2dd as another query with same id is already active. Perhaps you are attempting to restart a query from checkpoint that is already active."* then you need to delete the *checkpoint* folder location, by default the folder `/var/lib/spark/data/checkpoints/spark_streaming_kafka_checkpointPath_berka` hardcoded hereunder

msg.data:
B) Spark Streaming Program : reading from kafka input topic, computing aggregate and sending result to kafka output topic

This Spark SQL Structured Streaming programs reads some transactions from the Berka Dataset (resulting from the “Spark Integration ES” Demo notebook) from a kafka input topic as sent by the program A above. It then enriches them slightly and sends them back to a kafka output topic. The first program above then dumps them on the console.

Important Notes:

  • The Kafka bootstrap server is extracted from the Eskimo topology (variable SELF_IP_ADDRESS gives external IP Address and then SELF_MASTER_KAFKA_XXX gives kafka server to use)
  • The logs of the spark driver are available in the spark zeppelkin interpreter logs which you shall find in /var/log/zeppelin/zeppelin-interpreter-spark-*.log on the node executing zeppelin
  • CAUTION - SPARK STREAMING PROGRAM IS NOT PROPERLY TERMINATED BY ZEPPELIN !!! For this reason, a small paragraph is provided right hereafter so setup a specific name for the spark application which will be used in the last paragraph to stop (kill) the spark streaming program

Other notes:

  • In case you encounter an error such as “java.lang.IllegalStateException: Cannot start query with id 9c7acfc7-da52-4282-a012-3c3cbd8aa2dd as another query with same id is already active. Perhaps you are attempting to restart a query from checkpoint that is already active.” then you need to delete the checkpoint folder location, by default the folder /var/lib/spark/data/checkpoints/spark_streaming_kafka_checkpointPath_berka hardcoded hereunder

paragraphs.text:
%spark.conf
# override spark application name to enable t osearch it later on
spark.app.name spark-integration-kafka-demo

%pyspark


from pyspark import SparkContext, SparkConf
from pyspark.sql import SQLContext, SparkSession
from pyspark.sql.types import *
import pyspark.sql.functions as F
from pyspark.storagelevel import *
import math
import os

KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVER="kafka.eskimo.svc.cluster.eskimo:9092"

# Every time there is a shuffle, Spark needs to decide how many partitions will 
# the shuffle RDD have. 
# 2 times the amount of CPUS in the cluster is a good value (default is 200) 
NUM_PARTITIONS=2

        
# Zeppelin calls the spark session "spark
# ss is perhaps politically unsure but is really much more standard
ss = spark

ss.conf.set("spark.sql.shuffle.partitions", NUM_PARTITIONS)


# Query configuration only (cannot pass any ES conf here :-( )
es_query_conf= { 
    "pushdown": True
}

df = ss \
  .readStream \
  .format("kafka") \
  .option("kafka.bootstrap.servers", KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVER) \
  .option("subscribe", "berka-payments") \
  .option("failOnDataLoss", "false") \
  .load() 


# define shema 
schema = StructType([ \
    StructField("value_date", StringType()), \
    StructField("disp_access_type", StringType()), \
    StructField("account_frequency", StringType()), \
    StructField("account_id", StringType()), \
    StructField("region_name", StringType()), \
    StructField("district_name", StringType()), \
    StructField("@timestamp", StringType()), \
    StructField("transaction_type", StringType()), \
    StructField("client_birth_number", StringType()), \
    StructField("amount", StringType()), \
    StructField("disp_id", StringType()), \
    StructField("beneficiary_bank", StringType()), \
    StructField("k_symbol", StringType()), \
    StructField("client_id", StringType()), \
    StructField("client_district_id", StringType()), \
    StructField("beneficiary_account", StringType()), \
    StructField("operation", StringType()), \
    StructField("balance", StringType()), \
    StructField("trans_id", StringType()), \
    StructField("account_district_id", StringType())
])

# extract json
payments_df = df.select(F.from_json(df.value.cast('string'), schema) \
        .alias("json")) \
        .select ("json.*") \
        .withColumn("day_of_month", F.dayofmonth(F.col('@timestamp'))) \
        .withColumn("day_of_week", F.date_format(F.col('@timestamp'), 'EEEE')) \
        .repartition(NUM_PARTITIONS, "client_id") \
        .alias("payments_df")
        
        
# TODO do a little more
        
       


# Create output DataFrame
to_kafka_payments_df = payments_df \
        .select(F.col("trans_id").cast("string"), F.to_json(F.struct("*"))) \
        .toDF("key", "value") 

#payments_df \
#    .writeStream \
#    .trigger() \
#    .format("console") \
#    .start() \
#    .awaitTermination() 

#continuous="1 second"
#processingTime='100 milliseconds'


# Start streaming
to_kafka_payments_df \
  .writeStream \
  .trigger(processingTime='100 milliseconds') \
  .format("kafka") \
  .option("kafka.bootstrap.servers", KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVER) \
  .option("topic", "berka-payments-aggregate") \
  .option("checkpointLocation", "file:/var/lib/spark/data/checkpoints/spark_streaming_kafka_checkpointPath_berka4") \
  .start() \
  .awaitTermination() 


# Write to .eskimo
#payments_df.writeStream \
#   .trigger(processingTime='200 milliseconds') \
#   .format("org.elasticsearch.spark.sql") \
#   .outputMode("append") \
#   .option("checkpointLocation", "file:/tmp/spark_streaming_es_checkpointPath") \
#   .start("berka-streaming-profiled-payments/doc") \
#   .awaitTermination()


# # (3) Collect result to the driver
# payments_list = payments_df.collect()
# 
# print ("Printing 10 first results")
# for x in payments_list[0:20]:
#     print x
# 
# # Print count 
# print ("Computed %s positions (from collected list)") % len (payments_list)

%md

### C) STOP the Spark Streaming Program 

Unfortunately, zeppelin is not able to properly stop the spark streaming program. Use the following paragraph to do this

msg.data:
C) STOP the Spark Streaming Program

Unfortunately, zeppelin is not able to properly stop the spark streaming program. Use the following paragraph to do this

paragraphs.text:
%sh

#ps -efl | grep "spark-integration-kafka-demo" | grep java | grep -v grep | sed 's/  */ /g'

SPARK_PROCESS=`ps -efl | grep "spark-integration-kafka-demo" | grep java | grep -v grep | sed 's/  */ /g' | cut -d ' ' -f 4`

echo "Killing Spark Process PID $SPARK_PROCESS"

if [[ "$SPARK_PROCESS" != "" ]]; then
    kill -HUP $SPARK_PROCESS
fi


# I should pass an application name in the above that I would be able to grep here !

%md

#### Congrats ! You ran a spark streaming program

msg.data: Congrats ! You ran a spark streaming program
